project: International Master in Technology and Management for Circular Economy
International Master in Technology and Management for Circular Economy
text: What made you choose the IMATEC study program?I couldn’t properly decide whether to study rather technology or management for my Master’s. When I found out that the IMATEC program combines them both and in addition includes study experience in other countries, my decision was made.

project: International Master in Technology and Management for Circular Economy
text: Do you have a tip for applicants?Be honest and self-confident in your application – in the motivation letter, and during the interviews. It will most probably lead to the moment when you will enjoy your studies because your profile and expectations match the program content.

project: International Master in Technology and Management for Circular Economy
text: What would you recommend to new IMATEC students?Discover what subjects or topics you may like. Take advantage of this possibility to try things that you might never notice exist. Challenge the boundaries of your comfort zone! 😊

project: International Master in Technology and Management for Circular Economy
text: What was the hardest part of your studies so far?The hardest was moving between the countries, getting used to new customs, new ways of living, and also the logistics that go along with that. But with every other semester, it is getting better and easier.

project: International Master in Technology and Management for Circular Economy
text: What was the best part of your studies so far?The best part was definitely meeting my fellow students! Getting to know their culture, understanding their point of view, but also realizing the amount of similarities, not only differences. I found here people I wish would remain in my life forever.

project: International Master in Technology and Management for Circular Economy
International Master in Technology and Management for Circular Economy
text: What made you choose the IMATEC study program?The opportunity to study such an impactful subject as circular economy in two different dimensions – Technology and management – has caught my attention since the beginning. In my opinion, IMATEC is a Master’s program that gives you an interdisciplinary way to be a future Circular Economy professional with a complete background to start your career in this field. Besides, the chance to live in three different European countries and experience their lifestyle is an amazing factor that teaches us so much and enriches our world perspectives!

project: International Master in Technology and Management for Circular Economy
text: Do you have a tip for applicants?It is important to put effort into the preparation of the required documents. Besides the “traditional” ones such as previous studies transcripts, passport, or any other ID, it is worth writing a motivation letter that not only gives an introduction of you and your reasons for applying but also reflects your beliefs in pursuing a career in Circular Economy, and in being a future agent against Climate Change. In addition, of course, be aware of the deadline and avoid finishing the application on the last day!

project: International Master in Technology and Management for Circular Economy
text: What would you recommend to new IMATEC students?The IMATEC program provides a fulfilling and unique lifetime experience, but be aware of the changes along the way. You will be living in different countries and moving every six months. You will have to deal with a lot of variables at the same time: a new study routine, a new city, language, and even daily items you will have to discover and adapt, for example: where should I do my groceries? Or how does the public transport work here? I know it seems simple, but in the end, when all of that is combined, it can be overwhelming. Thus, be open-minded and resilient, this will make the experience go more smoothly, and try to appreciate the opportunities of growing along the journey!

project: International Master in Technology and Management for Circular Economy
text: What was the hardest part of your studies so far?I believe the hardest part is to combine the adaptation process to a new culture with the new study routine that each University demands. Not only we were moving from city to city, but the Universities present different ways of lecturing, doing the examination, and so on. It can be quite demanding to adjust to all of the factors at the same time.

project: International Master in Technology and Management for Circular Economy
text: What was the best part of your studies so far?I have to say that the content of the subjects is my favorite part! After one year of the Master’s, I feel that I am on the right track to move my career to the Circular Economy field. It has been a rich experience, full of new concepts and real-life applications. It is so satisfactory to know more about the field and to see this knowledge being applied worldwide. Also, I like to see how the subjects complement themselves during the Master’s semesters. For example, even currently studying at Åbo Akademi, I can affirm that I still remember and apply what I learned at UCT Prague.

project: International Master in Technology and Management for Circular Economy
International Master in Technology and Management for Circular Economy
text: I chose IMATEC because I want to build a career in waste and wastewater management. A master in circular economy gives more insight into innovative ways of use of resources derived from the waste management process in order to achieve zero waste. A master in circular economy challenges me to think outside the box and to research more innovative technologies, processes and products that are more sustainable and greener to the planet.

project: International Master in Technology and Management for Circular Economy
text: Ironically, the best part of my studies so far is not the academics even though that has also been great. I enjoy learning about other cultures and this Erasmus journey gives me the opportunity to do that. By interacting with diverse cultures, I have had the opportunity to share my culture and also learn a lot about other cultures.

project: International Master in Technology and Management for Circular Economy
text: To the incoming cohorts, I am an introvert and so I understand how difficult it is to leave familiarity behind and start afresh in Europe. My advice is to be yourself and take part in some of the many activities offered and over time as you make friends, you will feel less alone and isolated. And always ask for help if you need it; it is ok not to know everything.

project: International Master in Technology and Management for Circular Economy
International Master in Technology and Management for Circular Economy
text: What made you choose the IMATEC study program?I believe IMATEC is the ideal program that integrates all the key concepts I need to achieve my goals: materials science, waste management, sustainability, entrepreneurship, and life cycle assessment. The integration of chemical engineering, management, and business governance knowledge will provide me with a holistic and multifaceted approach to addressing sustainability and advancing the circular economy. This broad and extensive skill set will empower me to develop innovative solutions for real-world environmental challenges.

project: International Master in Technology and Management for Circular Economy
text: What was the hardest part of your studies so far?Moving from one country to another can be a double-edged sword. I consider it as one of the best parts since I get to live in 3 totally different countries, learning about the idiosyncrasies of each nation, whether it’s their people, weather, culture, food and/or language. I not only discovered a lot about myself, but also learn new things, travel around and explore different places. However, moving is also a struggling and challenging experience. With all the unpacking/packing hassles, adjustments and basically starting to adapt again. Also, since we will be studying in three universities, each one has its own system, rules and grading. It can be a daunting task at first, but it goes easy with time.

project: International Master in Technology and Management for Circular Economy
text: What was the best part of your studies so far?First, it was a truly a great opportunity to study at three prestigious universities, learn more about circularity encompassing science, technology, and management. Secondly, studying at these universities expanded my network and made me more curious about other concepts, and not box my technical knowledge on what I know now, but to think further and deeper. Lastly, I am also genuinely happy to meet similar minded people who I now consider my friends, and maybe even colleagues in the near future.

project: International Master in Technology and Management for Circular Economy
International Master in Technology and Management for Circular Economy
text: What made you choose the IMATEC study program?I chose the IMATEC program because it was a newly introduced program in the Erasmus Mundus catalogue, and its focus aligned perfectly with my interests and long-term goals. I have always been passionate about reducing waste, promoting recycling, and improving environmental sanitation in Nigeria. This concern stems from the lack of systems in Nigeria to effectively manage and recycle plastic waste. The country is overrun with plastic bottles that could be repurposed into clothes, bags, leather, or even new plastics, yet we continue to rely heavily on the importation of new materials. The IMATEC program presented the opportunity to learn advanced technologies in waste management, environmental sustainability, and materials engineering, which I believe are essential for tackling these pressing issues.

project: International Master in Technology and Management for Circular Economy
text: What would you recommend to new IMATEC students?My advice to new IMATEC students is to make the most of every moment. It’s important not to miss any opportunities for fun and relaxation because you will need them to balance the demands of the program. Erasmus programs are known for being rigorous, and there will be both challenging and rewarding times. To avoid feeling overwhelmed, be sure to explore your surroundings and enjoy your time. However, while having fun, don’t lose sight of your academic goals. It’s crucial to stay focused on your studies. Engaging in group discussions or study sessions can significantly enhance your understanding. While independent study works for some, learning with dedicated peers often leads to better results. Lastly, never hesitate to reach out to your professors or program coordinators when you need assistance. They are always willing to help, and their support has been invaluable to me. Best of luck with your journey!

project: International Master in Technology and Management for Circular Economy
text: What was the best part of your studies so far?The IMATEC program has exceeded my expectations from the very start. I’ve experienced exceptional lecture delivery by outstanding professors, well-equipped lecture rooms, industry visits, cultural exchanges, and networking opportunities. One of the highlights has been my summer internship at Bayer Hispania, a key branch of Bayer AG known for producing active pharmaceutical ingredients (APIs) for Aspirin. This industrial placement was fully organized by the program, and I am deeply grateful for that opportunity. Additionally, the program coordinators’ responsiveness and dedication to supporting students through any challenges or concerns have been remarkable. Their commitment to our success truly sets this program apart.

project: International Master in Technology and Management for Circular Economy
International Master in Technology and Management for Circular Economy
text: What made you choose the IMATEC study program?I chose the IMATEC program because it proposes a new and stimulating idea of integrating circular economy, technologies and management concepts in industries.

project: International Master in Technology and Management for Circular Economy
text: Do you have a tip for applicants?In your application, try to highlight what would you like to learn in the Master’s degree and how do you think this specif program would help you in your future career, which subjects and features of the program appeal to you and why.

project: International Master in Technology and Management for Circular Economy
text: What would you recommend to new IMATEC students?As a new student, try to balance your studies from the beginning of the semester with some time to socialize with your new classmates and also explore the cities you’ve just moved to. Along with the theoretical knowledge you will acquire in these two years, try to expand your network by getting to know your classmates, professors and locals. Keep in mind that there will be a lot of moving from one country to another, which can cause some anxiety, but in the end, it will all work out. Do your best to make the most of it!

project: International Master in Technology and Management for Circular Economy
International Master in Technology and Management for Circular Economy
text: What made you choose the IMATEC study program?Having seen the poor waste management practices in Uganda, I knew something could be done to handle the waste in a more sustainable manner. However, I still needed to gain further knowledge on the concept of sustainability and Circular Economy and therefore, while searching for scholarships, I was looking for a program that gave me an intersection between my undergraduate studies in chemical engineering and the future I wanted in environmental engineering. And after reading the curriculum of IMATEC, I remember saying “this is it!”.

project: International Master in Technology and Management for Circular Economy
text: Do you have a tip for applicants?Yes, for the IMATEC applicants, I would advice that you clearly know your motivation and explicitly explain it throughout the letter. Don’t leave room for the panelists to ask questions because you’ll have lost the chance to explain yourself since the deadline has passed. However, don’t be afraid to try… Like they say, “Shoot your shot”.

project: International Master in Technology and Management for Circular Economy
text: What would you recommend to new IMATEC students?Enjoy your time throughout the program, and as much as we all love to procrastinate, try to read a little bit of something every now and then because if left for last minute, it can get reaaally frustrating.

project: International Master in Technology and Management for Circular Economy
text: What was the hardest part of your studies so far?It would be the changes in the education systems per country. For example, I had never done an oral exam, and we had more than one at UCT, Prague. Also, language barrier can be challenging especially for a country like Spain, but they make up for it by being very nice. Trust that someone will smile at you at least once every day!

project: International Master in Technology and Management for Circular Economy
text: What was the best part of your studies so far?During a module on waste management, we picked Uganda as a case study. And it was great working with colleagues and understanding the challenges facing the country, some of the sustainable practices in place and suggesting what Uganda could do to improve her systems.

project: International Master in Technology and Management for Circular Economy
International Master in Technology and Management for Circular Economy
text: What made you choose the IMATEC study program?The field of circular economy and sustainable development is an emerging and highly popular area in China, while Europe has much more extensive experience in this domain. With my academic background in chemical engineering and energy, I am excited to join the IMATEC program, which offers the opportunity to study circular economy across Central, Southern, and Northern Europe, while also allowing time to experience the beautiful landscapes, diverse cultures, and climates of these regions.

project: International Master in Technology and Management for Circular Economy
text: What would you recommend to new IMATEC students?Living in new cultures and countries, along with frequent relocations, can really be a challenge for many people. Different institutions and professors in each country also have varying styles and expectations. Engaging with classmates and helping each other can accelerate our mutual progress. Don’t hesitate to seek assistance from others.

project: International Master in Technology and Management for Circular Economy
text: What was the best part of your studies so far?What impressed me the most was the cultural diversity. After spending a semester amidst the ancient and beautiful architecture of Prague, we began a new life under the sunny skies and along the azure coastlines of vibrant Spain. I deeply cherish the joyful times spent in Oviedo and Gijón, yet I also eagerly look forward to the Nordic life in Finland, where we will chase after snow and the Northern Lights.

project: International Master in Technology and Management for Circular Economy
International Master in Technology and Management for Circular Economy
text: What made you choose the IMATEC study program?I chose IMATEC as it is a program that offers me to study circular economy – an issue that is emerging now – in three different European countries. The IMATEC study program gives me the flexibility to choose one track out of three tracks available according to my interests and background. While focusing on one track, I am still able to learn some courses from different tracks, which equipped me with additional skills.

project: International Master in Technology and Management for Circular Economy
text: What was the hardest part of your studies so far?My hardest part of my studies is to adapt to a new study system every semester in each country. It is not a big problem, but it needs time to adjust myself every time we move.

project: International Master in Technology and Management for Circular Economy
text: What was the best part of your studies so far?The best part of my studies is that I have classmates from all around the world and we learn from each other. With the mobilities, we get to learn the technologies and practices in each country where we study in, which are different and it makes it more interesting.

project: International Master in Technology and Management for Circular Economy
International Master in Technology and Management for Circular Economy
text: What made you choose the IMATEC study program?The opportunity to do a master’s degree related to sustainability, management and technology because these are areas that I consider important for the future.

project: International Master in Technology and Management for Circular Economy
text: What was the hardest part of your studies so far?Being away from home for long periods and although it may sound paradoxical, sometimes when you already feel stable or comfortable in a country you know that you must move soon.

project: International Master in Technology and Management for Circular Economy
text: What was the best part of your studies so far?The knowledge in management and finance that I am acquiring at a top-level university.

project: International Master in Technology and Management for Circular Economy
International Master in Technology and Management for Circular Economy
text: What made you choose the IMATEC study program?As a chemical engineer, I was drawn to the program’s focus on circular economy. The opportunity to study at three prestigious universities across different countries while earning a triple degree was another key reason for choosing IMATEC.

project: International Master in Technology and Management for Circular Economy
text: What was the hardest part of your studies so far?The hardest part has been being away from family and friends. Leaving my comfort zone was challenging, but it’s helped me grow personally and professionally.

project: International Master in Technology and Management for Circular Economy
text: What was the best part of your studies so far?Meeting amazing people, learning from different perspectives, and experiencing diverse cultures has been the highlight of my studies.

project: International Master in Technology and Management for Circular Economy
International Master in Technology and Management for Circular Economy
text: What made you choose the IMATEC study program?IMATEC program is one of the few Erasmus Mundus Programs that focuses on Circular Economy, which is the future of this world’s economy. The integrated approach taken by this program through combining different management, technological, and scientific aspects of circular economy makes it one of a kind.

project: International Master in Technology and Management for Circular Economy
text: What would you recommend to new IMATEC students?Try to gain as much knowledge as you can from this program, and enjoy your life as much as you can as well. And most importantly, seek out to help whenever you need.

project: International Master in Technology and Management for Circular Economy
text: What was the hardest part of your studies so far?Adapting to different cultures and environments. Studying abroad will make you get out of your comfort zone and you will have to fit into different cultures.

project: International Master in Technology and Management for Circular Economy
text: What was the best part of your studies so far?Despite being the hardest part as well, but exploring different parts of the world by studying abroad is a unique experience that would transform your studies.

project: International Master in Technology and Management for Circular Economy
International Master in Technology and Management for Circular Economy
text: What made you choose the IMATEC study program?I first learned about the IMATEC program through an email from my university. After reviewing the details on the program’s webpage, I was immediately drawn to the wide range of opportunities it offers. The international nature of the program and the emphasis on interdisciplinary studies made it an ideal choice for me.

project: International Master in Technology and Management for Circular Economy
text: Do you have a tip for applicants?I don’t have any specific tips, but I would suggest that applicants thoroughly research the program and ensure it aligns with their career ambitions. Being proactive and open to new opportunities can be very beneficial.

project: International Master in Technology and Management for Circular Economy
text: What would you recommend to new IMATEC students?I highly recommend being as open-minded as possible and making the most out of every opportunity to study or intern abroad. Engaging with people from diverse backgrounds and gaining international exposure will not only enhance your academic experience but also contribute to your personal and professional growth.

project: International Master in Technology and Management for Circular Economy
text: What has been the hardest part of your studies so far?One of the most challenging aspects has been relocating frequently and adjusting to new environments. Meeting new people and being away from family can be tough at times. However, it has also been an opportunity for personal growth and resilience.

project: International Master in Technology and Management for Circular Economy
text: What has been the best part of your studies so far?The best part has definitely been the people I have met along the way. Experiencing different academic approaches and interacting with students and faculty from various cultural backgrounds has been enriching. I particularly enjoyed immersing myself in the distinct cultures of Spain and Finland, which broadened my perspective both academically and personally.

project: International Master in Technology and Management for Circular Economy
International Master in Technology and Management for Circular Economy
text: What made you choose the IMATEC study program?I chose the IMATEC program because it aligns with my belief that Circular Economy is key to achieving a sustainable future. The program’s focus on this emerging field offers the perfect opportunity for me to tackle environmental challenges using both scientific and managerial approaches.

project: International Master in Technology and Management for Circular Economy
text: What would you recommend to new IMATEC students?Enjoy this experience to the fullest! Learn from your classmates and teachers, as well as all the growth opportunities that this program offers such as summer school, internship, and field trips. Don’t forget the trips and adventures with your new friends!

project: International Master in Technology and Management for Circular Economy
text: What was the best part of your studies so far?Being part of such a culturally and academically diverse group, expanding my mind and knowledge as well as learning to adapt to these differences.

project: International Master in Technology and Management for Circular Economy
International Master in Technology and Management for Circular Economy
text: What made you choose the IMATEC study program?What drew me to the IMATEC program was its interdisciplinary approach. While the program offers specific tracks, the interconnected nature of the curriculum allows students to gain exposure to a broad range of topics. This balance between specialization and cross-disciplinary learning was a key factor in my decision.

project: International Master in Technology and Management for Circular Economy
text: Do you have a tip for applicants?I encourage prospective applicants to thoroughly prepare before applying. Familiarize yourself with software tools such as LABVIEW, ASPEN PLUS, and Excel, as they will be useful throughout the program. It’s also a good idea to spend some time learning the basics of the languages spoken in the countries where your host universities are located. Additionally, ensure that your application documents are clear, well-organized, and meet the program’s requirements. Take the time to carefully explore the IMATEC website so you have a solid understanding of the program and its expectations.

project: International Master in Technology and Management for Circular Economy
text: What was the best part of your studies so far?For me, the most enjoyable aspects of the IMATEC program include the excursions and laboratory work, especially given my background in chemistry. Moreover, the program coordinators and public relations officers are attentive and responsive, addressing any concerns that arise with care and efficiency.

project: International Master in Technology and Management for Circular Economy
International Master in Technology and Management for Circular Economy
text: What made you choose the IMATEC study program?Growing up in Zambia, a country heavily dependent on hydroelectricity, I was exposed to frequent power cuts due to over-reliance on this energy source, despite the abundance of sunlight. The reliance on copper mining further amplified my concerns about sustainability, as copper is a non-renewable resource, and Zambia’s mining practices did not seem sustainable. Before applying to IMATEC, I worked for a consultancy firm where I saw first-hand the negative effects of not utilizing resources efficiently, and the lack of implementation of circularity principles, such as reusing materials and leveraging naturally available resources—whether in energy generation, rural sanitation, or copper mining.

project: International Master in Technology and Management for Circular Economy
text: Initially, I believed the solution to these challenges was purely an engineering one. However, after working with various consultants, I realized the complexity of the issue and the need for skills beyond engineering – particularly in finance, management, and governance. So, when I discovered IMATEC, I was thrilled by the program’s holistic approach. It doesn’t just focus on the engineering aspects but also integrates management and science, which aligns perfectly with the solutions I wish to bring to Zambia. IMATEC’s comprehensive and preventative approach to circularity is what drew me to the program.

project: International Master in Technology and Management for Circular Economy
text: Do you have a tip for applicants?My advice is to go beyond focusing solely on your academic achievements. To make your application stand out, it’s important to gain practical experience, whether through work, volunteering, or international exposure. Additionally, having someone review your statement of purpose and CV can be incredibly helpful. Lastly, preparation is key. Start preparing early, even if you’re planning to apply in a couple of years. Research how to make your application competitive because, as the program becomes more established, the competition increases.

project: International Master in Technology and Management for Circular Economy
text: What was the hardest part of your studies so far?For me, the most challenging part was learning management courses like finance, as they were entirely new to me. However, I would reassure new students that these subjects are not too difficult as long as you are proactive, particularly by working through homework before attending lessons. It makes understanding the material much easier.

project: International Master in Technology and Management for Circular Economy
text: What was the best part of your studies so far?

project: International Master in Technology and Management for Circular Economy
text: The best part of the IMATEC program has been the opportunity to travel to different countries and interact with people from diverse cultures. text: The Joint Erasmus Mundus programme IMATEC aims to educate a new generation of engineers, managers, and scientists that can provide adequate and state-of-the-art environmental technology and engineering solutions which can be realistically implemented to tackle complex, multidisciplinary environmental issues.

text: Successful graduates will acquire a comprehensive knowledge of advanced technologies for sustainable use of natural resources, life cycle assessment of these technologies, management, and legal and administrative aspects of the circular economy. They will also have an overview of the latest trends in research and development of new environmental technologies.

The lecturers will come both from academic and non-academic associated partners (universities, research institutions, non-profit organizations, industry). Each topic proposal includes a short summary of the proposal, indicating the supervising university, the track and the potential participation of other institutions. The thesis has to be supervised by a supervisor from one of the three universities.

project: International Master in Technology and Management for Circular Economy
text: The number of topics at each university corresponds to, at least, one-third of the total number of students enrolled in the 3rdsemester of their studies. Each student will submit a prioritized list of chosen topics to the coordinator. Based on the students’ prioritized topics, the coordinator will assign a topic to each student. In case more students have the same priority, the selection is done considering the academic performance during the first two semesters.

text: The University of Oviedois a public institution of higher education and research in the Principality of Asturias. With over 400 years of history, it offers a full range of undergraduate degrees adapted to the European Higher Education Area (EHEA) in all branches of knowledge and postgraduate degree programmes in collaboration with national and international universities and more than 250 companies.

project: International Master in Technology and Management for Circular Economy
text: Teaching takes place on seven campuses spread over the central region of Asturias: Oviedo (El Cristo, El Milán, Llamaquique, Catalanes and Oviedo-Centre), Gijón and Mieres, in addition to offering various university services in Avilés. In 2010, it carried out an ambitious process involving the merger of centers linked to the Campus of International Excellence and has been set as an example of best practices for Spanish universities. As a result, the University has 16 Faculties and Schools, four affiliated institutions and the Professional School of Physical Education and Sports Medicine. Moreover, the International Center for Postgraduate Studies manages the Master’s Degrees and PhD Programmes.

text: Åbo Akademi University is the Swedish-language multidisciplinary academic university in Finland. We offer both undergraduate and graduate studies to some 5 500 students on two campuses, in Turku and Vaasa. Alongside our internationally renowned research and education, we endeavour to enhance diversity, inclusion, equality and sustainability.

text: Professor Bartáček is involved in various processes of recycling resources from tap water. These include energy-positive or energy-saving processes (anaerobic fermentation, bioflocculation, nitritation-anammox), grey water recycling or the production of specific organic substances. In recent years, he has also been intensively involved in so-called Wastewater-Base Epidemiology. In particular, the spread of antibiotic-resistant bacteria in wastewater and sewage sludge and the monitoring of the occurrence of viral epidemics (SARS-CoV-2, MPOX) in wastewater. Within the framework of these activities, he collaborates with other universities and a number of state research organizations and participated in the establishment of the Czech Antibiotic Resistance Platform CZEPAR.

text: Professor Kubička deals with the use of heterogeneous catalysis for the conversion of substances obtained from biomass processing into valuable chemicals and advanced biofuels. This includes the selective hydrogenation of phenolic and furanic substances into potential monomers usable in the production of bioplastics and the deoxygenation (total hydrogenation) of phenolic and furanic substances into components of future aviation biofuels. The subject of the research is the development, characterization and testing of catalysts in these reactions.

text: Ivan Souček graduated in plastics production and processing technology and started his professional career as an operations technologist at Kaučuk Kralupy. During the 11 years there he worked his way up to head of the strategic planning department, an area he has been involved in ever since. Among his job was also negotiating with potential foreign partners and drawing up long-term strategic plans, and in 1995 this work led to Ivan being one of the first three employees to found Unipetrol and later to participate in the creation of the joint stock company Česká rafinérská. At Unipetrol, he was involved in strategic planning, research, development and investment and became a member of the Board of Directors. Other work experience includes the position of General Manager of Koramo Kolín and Česká rafinérská a.s., later in 2012-2015 managing the preparation of a large refinery project abroad. Since 2016, he has been a director of the Association of Chemical Industry of the Czech Republic, an association that provides advocacy, education support, communication with the state and European administration, and support to member organizations in selected areas related to the chemical industry. They also promote chemistry to the public and bring together companies and research institutions and schools.

project: International Master in Technology and Management for Circular Economy
text: Throughout his rich industrial career, Ivan has also devoted himself to his studies. After graduating from University of Chemical Technology of D.I. Mendeleev in Moscow, he took several domestic and  international managerial and economics courses – including a studies at the University of Economics in Prague, 2-year course from the DePaul University Chicago, a 2-month production management course in Tokyo, and a 1-year sector economics and management post graduated course in Milano. Finally, he successfully completed his PhD studies at the University of Chemistry and Technology in Prague, department of Economics and Management.

project: International Master in Technology and Management for Circular Economy
text: However, he continues to teach at University of Chemistry and Technology in Prague since 2011 and is the author of nine books on strategic planning and investment decision making and more than a hundred articles and conference papers so far.

text: Jan Vlachýspent 25 years of his professional career in the domestic and international finance industry, gradually assuming responsibility for Treasury, Risk Management, Financial Markets and General Management. He was personally involved in numerous IPO and Structured Finance transactions, as well as in corporate reorganizations and in the implementation of the EU Capital Requirements Directive. More recently, he proceeded to pursue an academic path with research and teaching interests in Finance, Decision-making and Economic History. He also took responsibility for the development and management of international projects and study programs at the University of Chemistry and Technology PragueSchool of Business.

text: José Ramón Alvarez Saiz is a Chemical Engineering Professor at the University of Oviedo, with expertise in separation processes and membrane technology. His research focuses on applications such as industrial waste treatment, heavy metal abatement, and biorefinery processes, contributing significantly to the pulp and paper industry. He has participated in five regional, nine national, and two European projects, and has engaged in 27 industrial contracts, demonstrating a strong link between academic research and industrial needs. He has published 52 peer-reviewed articles and nine book chapters, and has contributed to 89 conference presentations. He has supervised eleven completed Ph.D. theses, with two more in progress. José Ramón holds one patent and is a co-organizer of the “Engineering with Membranes” conference series. He has been an instructor in international courses and a reviewer for Spanish and European funding agencies, highlighting his commitment to knowledge dissemination and academic excellence.

text: Estefanía’s scientific area is analytical chemistry, namely (bio)electroanalysis. She has developed a wide variety of electrochemical sensors, mainly enzymatic and immunosensors, for clinical applications, based on commercial electrochemical cells as transducers (mainly screen-printed electrodes), and employing diverse nanomaterials as modifiers and/or labels. In the last years, she has worked on the design and fabrication of low-cost miniaturized analytical platforms combining daily-used materials, such as paper, pins or pencil leads, with clinical, but also food and environmental applications. Estefanía also has worked on the synthesis of molecular imprinted polymers for analytical applications and the coupling of electrochemical detection to amplification reactions of genetic material.

text: Fernando Díez is Full Professor of Chemical Engineering at the University of Oviedo since 2005. He has taught since 1983 in the B.Sc. and M.Sc. degrees in Chemical Engineering. His research interests are industrial and environmental applications of heterogeneous catalytic processes (oxidation, hydrodechlorination) and development of less conventional catalytic reactors, such as reverse flow or membrane reactors. He has participated in numerous research projects with regional, national, EU or industrial funding. Author of more than 90 published scientific articles and 2 patents.

text: Laura Faba is an Associate Professor at the Department of Chemical and Environmental Engineering, University of Oviedo, a position she has held since 2021. Her research focuses on developing sustainable processes for lignocellulosic biomass valorization, including catalytic production of liquid fuels, aromatics, sustainable solvents, and, more recently, monomers for green plastics. She has co-authored over 65 scientific articles published in international journals and holds one patent. Her research career has been primarily based at the University of Oviedo, with research stays at Åbo Akademi University (Turku, Finland) and CNRS (Lyon, France).

project: International Master in Technology and Management for Circular Economy

Additionally, she is a visiting lecturer at the Catholic University of Lille (France), where she participates in the “Green Chemistry & Sustainability Week.”

text: Alfonso Fernández González earned his BSc in Chemistry in 1997 and his MSc in Analytical Chemistry in 1999, both from the University of Oviedo. He then pursued a PhD in Analytical Chemistry at the same institution, focusing on the chemical analysis of antibiotics using organized media and biomimetic materials, and was awarded his degree in 2003. Following this, he moved to the Dresden University of Technology in Germany, where he conducted postdoctoral research for two years before returning to Spain in 2006. Upon his return, he worked at the Spanish National Council for Scientific Research and later rejoined the University of Oviedo, where he was appointed as an Assistant Professor in 2017. In 2021, he was promoted to Tenured Associate Professor. His research interests include photoluminescence spectroscopy, carbon dots, pattern recognition algorithms in analytical chemistry, and drug delivery.

text: Susana Luque Rodríguez is a Full Professor in Chemical Engineering at the University of Oviedo, Spain, specializing in membrane technology and process design. She earned her PhD in Chemical Engineering from the same university in 1995 and has held various academic positions there since. Her research focuses on applied membrane technology, particularly in hybrid processes. She has held several leadership roles, including Head of the Department of Chemical and Environmental Engineering (2016-2023), President of the European Membrane Society and since 2024 she is the Vice-Rector of Knowledge Transfer and Business Relations. She has also been involved in over 30 research projects and collaborated extensively with industry through more than 40 contracts. Her international experience includes visiting professorships and research affiliations in the USA and Europe.

text: Salvador Ordóñez is Full Professor at the Department of Chemical and Environmental Engineering of the University of Oviedo since 2012. His research interests are focused on the application of heterogeneous catalysis and chemical reactor technologies to different environmental problems (VOCs abatement, treatment of halogenated wastes, elimination of emerging pollutants in water, etc.), as well as on the development of processes based on sustainable or renewable raw materials (catalytic production of fuels and chemical products from inedible biomass, recovery of methane content in gases of mine venting, syngas upgrading to chemicals, pyrolysis oil upgrading, development of sustainable chemical hydrogen carriers). Adsorption processes, chemical processes simulation, and photocatalytic technologies also are among his research interests. He is the author or co-author of more than 250 scientific articles published in international journals (JCR-indexed journals), five patents, and several book chapters. As to the academic activity, he has taught since 1999 in the areas of knowledge of Chemical and Environmental Engineering in different B.Sc. and M.Sc. degrees. Prof. Ordóñez is currently Spanish representative in the Board of the European Federation of Catalysis Societies (EFCATS). From 2019, he is collaborator (coordinator from 2024) of the Spanish Research Agency (AEI), in the area of Chemical Science and Technology (CTQ).

(Chem.Eng.) is the first in Finland to hold a professorship in the relatively young field of Chemical Process Intensification, which focuses on cross-disciplinary approaches to enhance the productivity of industrial processes. His research interests are largely focused on the development and intensification of selective biorefinery-related processes, including direct conversion of CO2, with the help of catalysis, reactor development,  unconventional energy forms, and novel integration of reaction and separation technologies, as well as continuous processes.

text: Professor, Laboratory of Industrial ManagementMagnus Hellström is a Professor at the Laboratory of Industrial Management. His research interests revolve around business model changes when the industry (notably the marine/maritime industry or more broadly, the blue economy) adapts to a demand for more sustainable products and operations and to the principles of a circular economy. His current research projects can be divided into two distinct but connected streams. The first stream focuses on the shift in business models when industrial companies move towards service provision and smart and autonomous solutions. The second research stream focuses on sustainable (and circular) business models in industrial settings, especially in the maritime industry and on the need for reducing emissions (notably GHG) in shipping.

project: International Master in Technology and Management for Circular Economy
text: The Erasmus Mundus Joint Masters program International Master in Technology and Management for Circular Economy (IMATEC) is oriented on the emerging area of circular economy and bio-economy. The two-year Master multiple degree program offers high-quality vocational education, combining competencies in technology, entrepreneurship, management, planning, science, and research, all focused on circular economy.

project: International Master in Technology and Management for Circular Economy
text: Students are trained in advanced technologies for sustainable use of natural resources, life cycle assessment of these technologies, as well as management and legal and administrative aspects of the circular economy. They also gain an overview of the latest trends in research and development of new technologies.

project: International Master in Technology and Management for Circular Economy
text: Students will choose their major study track and one additional study area among (1) Technology, (2) Policy & Management, or (3) Science.

project: International Master in Technology and Management for Circular Economy
text: The graduates will be qualified for positions in technological companies (e.g. technology suppliers, consultants, or utilities), policymaking bodies (e.g. governmental agencies or NGOs), or R&D (academia or private sector). They will also acquire presentation and managerial skills, teamwork ability, work with information resources, and communication with professionals and the public.

project: International Master in Technology and Management for Circular Economy
text: The aim is to integrate the current study programs into a coherent study program dealing with technologies and management for the circular economy to provide an internationally attractive and topical Erasmus Mundus Joint Master (EMJM) program and to showcase European excellence in higher education.

project: International Master in Technology and Management for Circular Economy
text: The study program addresses the current transition from linear to a circular economy that will allow meeting the objectives of the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals (UN SDG) and is reflected in the EU development strategies including the European Green Deal and the EU action plan for the Circular Economy.

Joint Master's Degree Programme in Service Design Strategies and Innovations
text: The Art Academy of Latvia (AAL), in collaboration with esteemed partners, announces a groundbreaking initiative poised to reshape the landscape of higher education in service design. Through the "Joint Master's Degree Programme in Service Design Strategies and Innovations" (SDSI), the consortium aims to equip the next generation of leaders with the tools to navigate complex challenges within our evolving world.In a pivotal milestone reached in September 2022, AAL, on behalf of the SDSI consortium, signed a grant agreement with the European Education and Culture Executive Agency for Project No. 101082388, cementing the path forward for SDSI. Commencing with the academic year 2023/2024, SDSI has officially gained recognition as an Erasmus Mundus Joint Master's programme.In a rapidly transforming Europe, where socio-economic paradigms are undergoing profound shifts, SDSI emerges as a beacon of change. This innovative joint-degree programme brings together the Art Academy of Latvia as the coordinator partner, the University of Lapland and the Estonian Academy of Arts as full partners, and the Stockholm School of Economics in Riga as an esteemed associate academic partner.ÂThe programme imparts a holistic education to create versatile service innovators capable of driving transformation across public and private entities through strategic design, management, and creative leadership. SDSI's interdisciplinary curriculum fosters cross-specialization in design, business, technology, and social sciences, facilitating the emergence of graduates poised to facilitate change and contribute to socially responsible global service organizations.Running from October 1, 2022, to November 30, 2028, the project No. 101082388 envisages four student intakes, commencing with the 2023/2024 academic year. Each intake will admit around 30 international students, with a minimum of 121 students experiencing the programme's enriching journey. Notably, the project allocates scholarships of 1400 EUR per month for the Erasmus Mundus, NDICI (Neighbourhood, Development and International Cooperation Instrument), or IPA (Instrument for Pre-Accession Assistance) recipients among the top 81 students.SDSI promises an immersive international experience, with students embarking on at least two study periods of 30 ECTS in countries distinct from their residence - Latvia, Finland, and Estonia. The project boasts a grant amount of 4,899,600.00 EUR, of which 2,721,600.00 EUR are dedicated to student scholarships, exemplifying the consortium's commitment to fostering academic excellence.To augment the academic experience, SDSI consortium proudly welcomes two associate partners - the KuldÄ«ga District Municipality and the NGO âKuldÄ«ga Artistsâ Residence'' - who will enrich students' learning journey with invaluable extra-curricular and cultural experiences during their Latvian study tenure.For more information:https://erasmus-plus.ec.europa.eu/projects/search/details/101082388The European Education and Culture Executive Agency (EACEA), in the context of managing the Erasmus Mundus Joint Masters, collects and processes the personal data of some of the candidates. In particular, certain data of the scholarship holders and non-scholarship holders is shared with the Agency and treated according tothis privacy statement.

SSE Riga is a comparatively small school with 450 students and a dynamic international learning environment â 60% of the core faculty is international, and programmes are designed in close cooperation with its âparent schoolâ in Stockholm.Through active alumni from the Bachelorâs programme in Economics and Business, professional Executive MBA programme, various non-degree management training, Centre for Media Studies, and public debate and research activities, SSE Riga fulfils its mission to contribute to the economic, social and democratic development of the region.Within the Erasmus Mundus project No. 101082388 of the SDSI implementation, the Stockholm School of Economics in Riga undertakes the role of an associate partner.Â

text: Located in the western part of Latvia, approximately 150 km from the capital Riga, KuldÄ«ga is known as a creative centre in Latvia. The visual resemblance of a medieval town is a result of meticulous long-term policy implemented by KuldÄ«ga Municipality to preserve the authentic architectural details of local buildings and the cityscape, especially in light of a nomination for the UNESCO World Heritage List.Over the last few years, the trend of a growing number of creative start-ups can be observed. Benefits of studying SDSI in KuldÄ«ga include industry proximity for unlimited experience with service innovations, tourist destinations within walking distance and an affordable lifestyle.Within the Erasmus Mundus project No. 101082388 of the SDSI implementation, the KuldÄ«ga Municipality undertakes the role of an associate partner.Â

project: Joint Master's Degree Programme in Service Design Strategies and Innovations
text: KuldÄ«ga Artistsâ Residence is an NGO, established in 2014, that has undertaken the role of bringing artistic and cultural vibrations to the town through visual arts residency programmes, design and creative industries projects, international summer schools, year-round exhibition programmes and various public events â lectures, workshops and artistsâ talks.Since 2016, KuldÄ«ga Artists' Residence has been a zealous advocate for establishing the SDSI programme in KuldÄ«ga, working in close collaboration with the KuldÄ«ga Municipality and the Art Academy of Latvia. Since 2017, the Residence has supported the brand of KuldÄ«ga Creative Summer School annual SDSI service design summer workshops.Within the Erasmus Mundus project No. 101082388 of the SDSI implementation, the KuldÄ«ga Artists' Residence undertakes the role of an associate partner.Â

project: Joint Master's Degree Programme in Service Design Strategies and Innovations

text: Each year, the top 20 students will receive the prestigious Erasmus Mundus scholarship, providing them with a monthly stipend of 1400 EUR throughout the entirety of their SDSI study programme. It is important to highlight that the allocation of these scholarships is contingent upon student geography.Under the Grant agreement with the European Education and Culture Executive Agency for Project No. 101082388, spanning the project's 2022-2028 timeline, the SDSI programme is authorized to grant scholarships as follows: 60 scholarships for students hailing from Erasmus+ Programme Countries, 3 scholarships for students originating from Instrument for Pre-Accession Assistance (IPA) region countries, and 18 scholarships for students from countries falling under the Neighbourhood, Development, and International Cooperation Instrument (NDICI) region.In accordance with the guidelines set forth by the Erasmus+ Programme Guide, this scholarship serves as a financial support mechanism, addressing students' travel, visa, installation, and subsistence expenses. Moreover, an all-encompassing health insurance coverage will be extended to all students, regardless of scholarship status.Important:candidates who have already benefited from an Erasmus Mundus Joint Master (EMJM) scholarship are not eligible to apply for an additional scholarship.Regrettably, as stipulated by the Grant agreement with the European Education and Culture Executive Agency for Project No. 101082388, the SDSI programme lacks dedicated funding for students with special needs. Nonetheless, the SDSI university partners remain steadfast in their commitment to offer comprehensive assistance to individuals requiring additional support, to the best of their capabilities.

text: A notary is a lawyer or person with legal training who is licensed by the government to perform acts in legal affairs. Notarization is the act of officially certifying a legal document by a public notary. The purpose of having a legal document notarized is to ensure the authenticity of the signatures that appear on the document. Notarization is a verification that a document together with the signature attached to it is authentic.âPlease note that all the requested documents need to be prepared correctly and sent to us in one complete set on time. text: Please read the Selection Criteria carefully before submitting an appeal. Applicants who do not submit the required documents by the established deadlines should not appeal.

text: The appeals process refers to how your proposal was handled during the evaluation and eligibility process. It is not an automatic re-evaluation. Please note that any new information or clarifications that should have been included in your proposal will not be considered. If, after reading the above conditions, you still have reason to believe that an error has been made, please send an email with all required information (name, email address, and a detailed explanation of why you believe an error has been made) to the Head of SDSI Ilze KundziÅa at ilze.kundzina@sdsi.ma so that the SDSI Admissions Committee can conduct a reconsideration. All appeals must be submitted before April 4, 2025. Appeal results will be emailed to the applicant before April 18, 2025.

text: After the final acceptance you will have to prepare your documents for the residence permit to start your studies in SDSI. Your first study location is Latvia and therefore it is also the country to submit your application for the residence permit. You will be able to find the additional information about the documents needed for theinitial residence permit for studieshere:https://vissparmigraciju.pmlp.gov.lv/. Select your country and proceed to the next steps.

project: Joint Master's Degree Programme in Service Design Strategies and Innovations
Joint Master's Degree Programme in Service Design Strategies and Innovations
text: Make sure that before arriving to Latvia you have obtained the original paper-signeddocument certifying the necessary means of subsistence. Monthly amount in EUR is country specific and indicated in the section "Documents to be submitted". You have to present the means of subsistence for the time period of one year at least. Make sure that the document has the original signature, full name, job position of the signature person, and name of the financial institution issuing the document. The sum has to be indicated in EUR. Take this document with you when arriving to Latvia â you will have to submit it together with other docs during the process of obtaining the residence permit.

project: Joint Master's Degree Programme in Service Design Strategies and Innovations
text: Before applying for a residence permit, ensure that your criminal records do not require double legalization. For guidance on proper legalization, please reach out to the Consular Department of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs in Latvia at mfa.cdep@mfa.gov.lv or call +371 67 015 905. Taking these steps will help streamline your residence permit application process.

project: Joint Master's Degree Programme in Service Design Strategies and Innovations
text: In order to obtain the residence permit, you will be requested to indicate theaddress of your residence during the studies in Latvia. Make sure that you start search of the rental apartment / dorms as soon as possible after admission to SDSI. Ask the SDSI incoming team for assistance.

project: Joint Master's Degree Programme in Service Design Strategies and Innovations
text: We suggest that youopen abank accountin a bank in Latvia. For non-EU/EEA students it is a must, and is possible after the residence permit by the Republic of Latvia is granted, within 90 days after starting your studies at SDSI. This will be the EU bank account for the whole duration of your study process. For Erasmus Mundus scholarship holders â it is where the SDSI scholarship will be monthly paid to, including during the mobility periods in Estonia and Finland. However, also non-Erasmus Mundus scholarship holders at some point might apply to and be awarded another kinds of national scholarships, and the EU bank account will then be needed. In addition, EU bank account allows you for low-cost or free of charge ATM transactions in the SDSI countries.Â

project: Joint Master's Degree Programme in Service Design Strategies and Innovations
text: In order to continue the SDSI mobility periods in Estonia and Finland, mobility instructions are pretty easy. Considering that the initial residence permit for non-EU students was granted by the Republic of Latvia in compliance with the EU study migration directive 2016/801 and covers your whole mobility path for the 2 yearsâ study programme, no additional visa or residence permit has to be obtained in Finland and Estonia by non-EU students. However, certain mobility registrations have to be implemented byall studentsin the following order:

project: Joint Master's Degree Programme in Service Design Strategies and Innovations
text: Semester inEstonia: Fornon-EU studentsit is enough to have the initial residence permit which was granted by the Republic of Latvia on your Year 1, and you are not requested to undergo any other migration procedures. However,EU studentshave to register their Estonian residence address and apply for the Estonian ID card; see instructions here:https://www.eesti.ee/en/.

project: Joint Master's Degree Programme in Service Design Strategies and Innovations
text: Semester inFinland:Non-EU studentsmust submit a mobility notification to the Finnish Immigration Service prior to the start of the mobility semester in Finland:https://migri.fi/en/. For non-EU students â again, keep in mind, that you donât need to apply for a new residence permit in Finland, based on the fact that you have a valid residence permit for studies issued by the Republic of Latvia, and your studies are covered by the SDSI consortiumâs agreement among higher education institutions.EU studentsÂ  must apply for the registration of the right of residence:https://migri.fi/en/.

text: Services impact our daily lives as consumers, customers and citizens. We live and work in an Experience Economy in which our jobs, prosperity, and quality of life are affected by the way in which services are designed and managed. Over the past few decades, the service sector has become the largest component of the economy in the EU, currently accounting for 70% of GDP and generating 90% of jobs in the region.

project: Joint Master's Degree Programme in Service Design Strategies and Innovations
Joint Master's Degree Programme in Service Design Strategies and Innovations
text: The service sector plays a crucial role in the organisation of our society and how we face and respond to societal challenges, from healthcare in an ageing society, access to amenities in regions with population decline, scaling up mobility in growing urban areas, and solving challenges in transportation, public services and the delivery of education.Â

project: Joint Master's Degree Programme in Service Design Strategies and Innovations
text: Technological innovations enable us to transform existing services and develop new ones that were previously unimaginable. The rapidly growing sharing economy, in which services and products are offered via online platforms, saw revenues doubling in the EU between 2014 and 2015. In 2016, one in six Europeans is said to have used these platforms.

project: Joint Master's Degree Programme in Service Design Strategies and Innovations
Joint Master's Degree Programme in Service Design Strategies and Innovations
text: The design and management of services is shaped by complex challenges. As opposed to products, services are intangible and cannot be owned or stored.

project: Joint Master's Degree Programme in Service Design Strategies and Innovations
text: Services are provided over time, with their provision and consumption often occurring simultaneously. Characterised by interaction touchpoints that are informed by the behaviours and experiences of users and service providers, quality control and innovation management remain challenging to service organisations.

project: Joint Master's Degree Programme in Service Design Strategies and Innovations
text: Service design emerged in the 1990s and has developed into a pivotal approach in private and public organisations to improve the quality and productivity of services. Service design aims to create services that are useful, usable, and desirable to clients and effective, efficient, and distinctive for suppliers.

project: Joint Master's Degree Programme in Service Design Strategies and Innovations
text: Service design is a multidisciplinary and integrative field. It involves practitioners and researchers from areas such as design, business, management, technology and social sciences.

project: Joint Master's Degree Programme in Service Design Strategies and Innovations
Joint Master's Degree Programme in Service Design Strategies and Innovations
text: Service Design Strategies and Innovations (SDSI) focuses on interdisciplinary studies and cross-specialisation in design, management, business and social sciences. We will help you become a versatile service innovator who can enable change in public and private organisations through strategic design, management and creative leadership.

project: Joint Master's Degree Programme in Service Design Strategies and Innovations
text: Around 30 students will be admitted to the programme annually, enabling individual and personalised approaches to the study process and providing close networking among students and teaching personnel.Â

project: Joint Master's Degree Programme in Service Design Strategies and Innovations
text: Graduates will be awarded with master's multiple degrees: Master of Arts (Art and Design) by the University of Lapland, Master of Design by the Art Academy of Latvia, Master of Arts by the Estonian Academy of Arts, as well as a joint diploma supplement. SDSI has strong connections to industry, ensuring research, design and testing opportunities with real industry partners on study topics and projects in Latvia, Estonia and Finland.

text: The study process includes study periods abroad to KuldÄ«ga in Latvia, Tallin in Estonia and Rovaniemi in Finland. SDSI locations are âsafe countriesâ characterised by societies striving for social and economic development, wellbeing, and culture.Through their international offices, partner countries offer well-established networks for finding suitable student accommodations and public transport, with airports nearby. Partner countries are internationally known for the beauty of their natural resources, green forests, and the Baltic Sea, and unlimited options exist for hiking, exploring, finding peace of mind and spending quality time on your studies.Â

project: Joint Master's Degree Programme in Service Design Strategies and Innovations
Joint Master's Degree Programme in Service Design Strategies and Innovations
text: Due to its picturesque and well-preserved medieval cityspace, KuldÄ«ga often serves as a stage for international filmmakers, artists and photographers. Creative ambience is the reason why the fresh, 2021-built SDSI campus building is located here. From KuldÄ«ga, you can access the beach in about 30 minutes, and the widest natural waterfall in Europe on the river Venta is located in the very centre of town. KuldÄ«ga is also known for its potential listing as a UNESCO World Heritage site, the slow-food culture, and a year-round arts and cultural programme.Â

project: Joint Master's Degree Programme in Service Design Strategies and Innovations
Joint Master's Degree Programme in Service Design Strategies and Innovations
text: The city of Rovaniemi on the Arctic Circle of Finnish Lapland is known as the official home of Santa Claus. The lure of magical white winters and romanticaurora borealistempt visitors to experience the stunning views and captivating, mysterious wilderness beyond the city streets. Visitors to the city may have to discover which of the eight seasons of Lapland they will experience and explore upon their stay.

project: Joint Master's Degree Programme in Service Design Strategies and Innovations
Joint Master's Degree Programme in Service Design Strategies and Innovations
text: Tallinn is the capital city of Estonia, located on the Baltic sea. First established in the early medieval era, todayâs Tallinn is an exciting mix of old and new. Tallinn is the first point of entry to Estonia for most visitors, and if youâre the kind of person who likes to jump right in, then youâre in luck, as Tallinn city centre is never more than 15-minutes drive away regardless of if you happen to arrive by plane, train, coach or ferry. Tallinn Old Town is one of the best preserved Hanseatic town centres in the world. A stoneâs throw away youâll find the cityâs business centre with modern towers and luxurious hotels, trendy neighbourhoods and large shopping centres. Tallinnâs luring coastline dotted with promenades and sandy beaches is especially rewarding during the summer but offers scenic views of the iconic cityscape and breathtaking sunsets throughout the year.

text: The Art Academy of Latvia was founded in 1919, and its expertise includes various fields of visual art and design. A modernised tradition of academic education, openness to topical art processes and activities, and a hands-on individual approach by the teaching personnel in preparing young artists have ensured and preserved the Academyâs authority.With 700 students, the Academy is characterised as an example of exceptionally good collaboration between students and their professors. 2021 marks a new era for the Academy by inclusion of service design in its curricula list and the newly built, modern campus in KuldÄ«ga, designed specifically for SDSI students.

project: Joint Master's Degree Programme in Service Design Strategies and Innovations
text: Originally established in 1979, the University of Lapland aimed to provide higher education opportunities for those living in the far reaches of northern Finland. Now the university has grown into an international, multidisciplinary university whose areas of expertise include art and design, education, law, social sciences, Northern and Arctic themes, and tourism research.Our first-class Arctic design labs support cutting-edge research on the interactions between people and the environment in the Arctic. Our interactions with community, businesses, and society are at the core of our research in northern Finland.

project: Joint Master's Degree Programme in Service Design Strategies and Innovations
text: Established in 1914, the Estonian Academy of Arts is one of six public universities in Estonia. It combines a unique mix of heritage and cutting-edge art and technology, as its small size allows for agility and constant innovation. As a school of 1000 students and a 1:3 teacherâstudent ratio, individualised study and personal mentorship are at the core of student development.The multitude of creative departments, many of which have been operating for close to a century, enable design students to be inspired by textile and fashion designers, blacksmiths, ceramists, sculptors and many others.

project: Joint Master's Degree Programme in Service Design Strategies and Innovations
text: The Financial Times-ranked Stockholm School of Economics in Riga (SSE Riga) is the leading business school in the region. SSE Riga is a comparatively small school with 450 students and a dynamic international learning environment â 60% of the core faculty is international, and programmes are designed in close cooperation with its âparent schoolâ in Stockholm.Through active alumni from the Bachelorâs programme in Economics and Business, professional Executive MBA programme, various non-degree management training, Centre for Media Studies, and public debate and research activities, SSE Riga fulfils its mission to contribute to the economic, social and democratic development of the region.Â

For these three programmes, you will not benefit from the Erasmus Mundus grant, but you can apply for financialsupportfromthe Erasmus Mobilityprogramme or from the university where you will apply.

text: ESA’s Young Graduate Trainee (YGT) Programme offers young graduates the opportunity to gain valuable on-the-job experience in the development and operation of space missions in an international and multicultural environment. The Programme lasts for one year and is a launch pad for many professional opportunities within Europe’s space sector, renowned research institutes or, of course, ESA itself.

project: Governance & Administration of Leisure and Sports International Master
text: Candidates fromall over the world can applyto the GOALS Erasmus Mundus Joint Master Degree.Both scholarship and self-funded applicants submit their application throughthe same online application form.

project: Governance & Administration of Leisure and Sports International Master
Governance & Administration of Leisure and Sports International Master
text: Academic requirementsCandidates must hold a Higher Education (HE) undergraduate degree (e.g., Bachelor, Licence, 180ECTS) or a recognised equivalent level of learning in accordance to the GOALS Master programme.The expected scientific background is the following: Sport management (sport sociology, sport marketing, sport communication, sport finances, sport economics, sport event management) or Management/business administration (sociology, marketing, communication, finances, economics, event management) or Sport studies (physical education, sport coaching, fitness, sport and wellness).âStudents enrolled in their last year of undergraduate degree can provide an official certificate of registration produced by their HE institution. If selected, they must provide their official degree or certificate of Bachelor degree achievement by the 30th of August, or their enrolment to the programme will be canceled.

project: Governance & Administration of Leisure and Sports International Master
text: Language proficiencyThe whole GOALS programme is taught in English and English proficiency is therefore a basic requirement. All non-English native speakers must attest a valid B2 English level (CEFR â Common European Framework of Reference) or equivalent:

text: You do not need to provide a motivation letter. However, you will be asked to express your motivation on the application platform. When a translation of the documents is needed, applicants should provide a copy of the original documents and their legal translation in English.Â

Governance & Administration of Leisure and Sports International Master
text: 1. Online applicationYou must fill in anonline application form, in English, and provide all required documents. Your online application must be submitted before the deadline of the call.After submission, you will receive an automatic acknowledgement of receipt by e-mail (check you spam box if not).

project: Governance & Administration of Leisure and Sports International Master
text: 2. Interview of shortlisted candidatesAfter a first analysis and ranking of the applications, a short list determines students to be interviewed by the evaluators. The 20 minutes interview is designed to explore candidatesâ motivation to study in the GOALS course, their critical thinking skills and understanding of social work issues. Candidates will also be allowed to ask questions about the GOALS course.Interviews will be conducted by videoconference.

project: Governance & Administration of Leisure and Sports International Master
text: 3. Final selectionFiles are reviewed and marked on a scale from very poor to outstanding, for each selection criteria by each partner university. Each file being examined three times thus receives three marks which are added and automatically averaged. The final ranking of applicants will be made by combining the scores from the paper applications (50%) with interview performance (50%). The generated ranking is used by the Selection and Examination Board to establish a selection of approximately 50 applicants.

text: Job offer - External Evaluator to EMJM GOALS

project: Governance & Administration of Leisure and Sports International Master
text: While implementing the Erasmus Mundus Design Measures â The GOvernance & Administration of Leisure and Sports International Master (GOALS) - https://master-goals.eu/ project, we are looking for an external evaluator to assess our first years of the project.âThe task of the external evaluation is to investigate, assess and evaluate the implementation of the project: learning outcomes, good management of the scholarships, employability of the student, etc.Applications will be scored and ranked according to the following criteria:- experience in external evaluation,- experience in EU-funded project management,- experience in the Erasmus Mundus programme,- motivation.The tasks:- assessment of the self-assessment report of each of the consortium partners (information about the teaching infrastructure, scientific potential of the staff employed at the faculty, information about the library and available books (also online), information about dormitories, information about the faculty's business partners, information about the study program implemented at the university),- evaluation of the recruitment of the best candidates for studies,- evaluation of the study program (mobility scheme),- evaluation of activities supporting the teaching process (readability of visa procedures, registration for the next semester, assistance in obtaining accommodation, bank account, information about the health system),- evaluation of student survey results,- assessment of communication (and promotion of communication) with potential candidates for studies,- evaluation of program financing, - assessment of communication with program graduates,- assessment of internships, job fair and study trips as a form of finding a job,- assessment of the possibility of finding a job based on the study program offered (employability).Required documents:- CV Deadline to apply: 6th May 2024Please send the documents to the e-mail address:consortium@master-goals.euDownload the job offer
